newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Leotard praises Juppe, says may stay on.
newsitem.headline: France's Leotard praises Juppe, says may stay on.

text.p: Embattled Prime Minister Alain Juppe won praise from a key ally on Friday who likened calls to sack him to demoting a victorious general if the centre-right coalition wins France's parliamentary election.

Francois Leotard, head of the Union for French Democracy (UDF) which is the junior partner in Juppe's coalition, said "it is not unimaginable" that Juppe could stay on despite polls showing that voters overwhelmingly want him out.
"If we win it means that he will have led the coalition to victory. I don't see generals getting demoted when they win battles," he told RTL radio of the National Assembly election on May 25-June 1.
Leotard stopped short of saying he wanted President Jacques Chirac to reappoint Juppe if the coalition wins, saying the decision was up to Chirac alone.

Polls show about two-thirds of voters want Juppe out because unemployment has risen to a record 12.8 percent since he came to office in 1995 promising a war for jobs. He is also held responsible for weak economic growth and political corruption scandals.
Juppe has sought to play down his personality as a campaign issue and insists he is not actively seeking re-election. "I'm not such a bad man," he said in an interview with the daily Le Parisien.

The daily France-Soir offered readers cut-out heads of various businessmen to stick on his shoulders after an opinion poll showed most French people would prefer a prime minister who was not a professional politician.
